Co-based catalysts exhibit considerable catalytic activity in oxidative reactions, yet challenges remain in synthesizing Co3O4 materials featuring both large surface area and high activity. Here, ultrathin La0.029CoOx nanosheets were post-treated with various concentrations of dilute nitric acid to obtain the two-dimensionally geometric Co3O4-H nanosheets catalysts. Among them, the resultant Co3O4-0.1H catalyst disclosed significantly enhanced catalytic activity, enabling to achieve 100 % conversion of benzene at 230 °C under an ultrahigh weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of 60,000 mL·g−1·h−1. Additionally, the catalyst also displayed excellent catalytic durability and well catalytic stability over 5 cyclic tests and 45 h of long-period operation. A thorough characterization results revealed that the superior catalytic performance of Co3O4-0.1H was attributed to its distinct nanosheet morphology, high specific surface area and abundant surface defect sites. This work highlights the effectiveness and simplicity of acid washing treatment strategy in improving the catalytic oxidation activity of transition metal oxide catalysts. Graphical Abstract Keywords Cobalt oxide Ultrathin nanosheets Catalytic oxidation Benzene Acid washing Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction As a typical representative of transition metal oxides, Co3O4 displaying excellent activity, durability and stability in various environmental relevant catalytic applications [1–3]. Structurally, the Co3+ ions coordinated by six lattice oxygen anions (O2-), form a hexacoordinated octahedral structure, while Co2+ ions coordinated by four O2- ions, occupy the center of a tetracoordinated tetrahedron, therefore the spinel-structured Co3O4 featuring high symmetry [4,5]. The similarity in outer electronic structures and oxygen coordination numbers between Co3+ and Co2+ facilitate electron exchange, which imparts excellent redox properties [6]. Besides, Co3O4 also possesses variable morphology, abundant surface oxygen species, and high stability, making it an effective catalyst for catalytic oxidation of gaseous pollutants [7–10]. Introducing rare earth elements like La into Co3O4 can alter its morphology and optimize its electronic structure, thereby enhancing the overall catalytic activity [11–13]. For instance, Wu et al.[14] demonstrated that in La-Co composite oxides, different metal monoxides exhibiting strong interactions with each other, thereafter performed significantly enhanced catalytic toluene oxidation activity at a relatively low reaction temperature. Yao et al.[15] also reported that La doping enable to transform Co3O4 nanoparticles into nanosheets, which was beneficial for increasing specific surface area, and preventing the accumulation of reaction intermediates, thereby avoiding the coverage of active sites and improving catalytic efficiency for propane destruction. In another study, Bae et al.[16] found La species inhibited surface hydroxyl formation, thus largely improving CO oxidation capacity even under high humidity condition. In our previous research [17], we synthesized a highly ultrathin and porous LayCoOx nanosheet catalyst, which exhibited superior catalytic performance for benzene oxidation. This was attributed to its high specific surface area, strong Co-La interaction, abundant adsorbed oxygen, and elevated Co3+ content. In La-based composites catalysts, La oxides are inert and contribute no catalytic activity. To further enhance catalytic efficiency, removing these inert components through acid treatment can be beneficial [18–21]. Due to different acid resistance, this process selectively removes La species but without compromising the inherent structure of transition metal-based oxides [22,23]. A study by Yang et al.[24] demonstrated that treating the LaCoO3 perovskite catalyst with acetic acid created a more porous and loose surface, which facilitated better reactant-catalyst contact and enabling the resultant catalyst displayed an improved catalytic toluene oxidation performance. Likewise, Si et al.[25] used nitric acid to fabricate the special MnO2/LaMnO3 structure, leading to enhanced toluene conversion due to increased surface area and nanopores. Chen et al.[26] employed citric acid treatment on LaCoO3, confirming that the improved toluene oxidation was stemmed from increased surface defect sites and oxygen vacancies. Combining the above-mentioned studies with our previous investigation [17], in this work, we synthesized a series of high-surface-area and mesoporous Co3O4-H catalysts by utilizing dilute nitric acid to wash ultrathin La0.029CoOx nanosheet precursor, with the resultant catalysts denoted as Co3O4-0.05H, Co3O4-0.1H, Co3O4-0.25H based on the usage of 0.05, 0.1 and 0.25 vol% of diluted nitric acid. Benzene was then selected as a model contaminant to evaluate the catalytic performance of the as-resultant catalysts. Alongside evaluating catalytic performance, we conducted comprehensive physicochemical characterizations, establishing a link between the structural modifications and the enhanced catalytic activity. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation Preparation of La 0.029 CoO x nanosheets: cobalt nitrate (2.91 g) and lanthanum nitrate (0.125 g) were dissolved in 100 mL of deionized water. Ammonium carbonate (3.5 g) was then added to this solution, the mixture was reacted at 90 °C for 2 h. After which the solution was centrifuged to obtain a precipitate, the precipitate was washed with deionized water and ethanol for several times, respectively. Next, the precipitate was dried in an oven at 70 °C for 12 h and ground into a fine powder. Finally, the powder was calcined in a muffle furnace at 300 °C for 2 h, with a heating rate of 5 °C min−1. The resulting sample was designated as La0.029CoOx [17]. Preparation of Co 3 O 4 nanosheets: Co3O4 nanosheets were synthesized using the same method described above but without the addition of lanthanum nitrate. Preparation of acid-etched nanosheets: 0.5 g of La0.029CoOx was mixed with 200 mL of 0.1 vol% dilute nitric acid solution. The mixture was filtered, and the resulting filter paper was washed with 400 mL of deionized water to remove any residual nitric acid. The filter paper was then putted in ventilated kitchen for 24 h, and the resulting sample was labeled as Co3O4-0.1H. Additionally, 0.5 g of La0.029CoOx treated with 200 mL of 0.05 vol% and 200 mL of 0.25 vol% nitric acid solutions, were denoted as Co3O4-0.05H and Co3O4-0.25H, respectively. Additionally, 0.5 g of pure Co3O4 treated with 200 mL of 0.1 vol% nitric acid solution was used as referenced sample, and named as Co3O4-T. 2.2 Catalyst characterizations The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the catalysts were obtained using a PANalytical X’Pert Powder diffractometer equipped with Cu Kα radiation (60 kV, 55 mA). Continuous scanning was recorded in the 2θ range from 10 to 70° at a rate of 5° min−1. The Brunauer−Emmett−Teller (BET) surface area measurements were performed using the MAX-II fully automated multistation surface and pore size analyzer (MicrotracBEL, Japan) at −196 °C. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM), high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) were carried out using a Talos F200S field emission transmission electron microscope (ThermoFisher Scientific, Netherlands). H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) and O2 temperature-programmed desorption (O2-TPD) of the catalysts were conducted using a Micromeritics AutoChem 2720 equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed on an ESCALAB250Xi spectrometer, and the C 1 s peak at a binding energy of 284.8 eV was used for calibration. 2.3 Catalytic performance evaluation Catalytic performance tests were evaluated in a micro-fixed-bed reactor (quartz tube, inner diameter Φ = 8.0 mm) using 0.050 g of catalyst. The feed gas for benzene oxidation consisted of 0.100 × 10−2 (1000 ppm) benzene and 40.1 × 10−2 O2, balanced with N2, with a total flow rate of 50 mL min−1, corresponding to a weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of 60,000 mL·g−1·h−1. The product concentrations were monitored online using a gas chromatograph (GC-9160) equipped with two flame ionization detectors (FID). The benzene conversion (X,%) was calculated according to the following formula. X = ( benzene in – benzene out ) / benzene in × 100 The weight hourly space velocity (WHSV, mL·g−1·h−1) was calculated as follows: WHSV = V / m = ( 50 × 60 )/ 0.050 = 60,000 mL · g − 1 · h − 1 Where V denotes the volume flow rate of the feed gas, and V = 50 mL·min−1. m denotes the amount of catalyst, and 0.050 g of catalyst was used for testing. In addition, the CO2 yield (Y, %) was calculated as follows: Y = CO 2 out / ( 6 × benzene in ) × 100 For catalytic cycle tests, after finishing up a benzene oxidation cycle, the reaction system is naturally cooling down to room temperature, and then a new cycle of testing is directly started upon using the same evaluating procedure. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalysts characterization Previously reported ultrathin La0.029CoOx nanosheet was explored as the solid catalyst precursor, which was synthesized by co-precipitation step along with additional thermal calcination treatment in a muffle furnace ( Fig. 1a) [17]. Notably, the reported La0.029CoOx is also an excellent catalyst with rich mesoporosity for benzene oxidation. As La species have no performance towards benzene oxidation, therefore, the removal of them in La0.029CoOx may yield a high-performance catalyst with enhanced physicochemical properties. Building on this hypothesis, in this work, the optimal 0.1 % vol of diluted nitric acid was used to remove the surface La species, resulting in the successful formation of ultrathin Co3O4-0.1H nanosheet with enlarged pore size, improved diffusion capability and more exposed surface defects sites for distinct benzene oxidation (Fig. 1b). In addition, a commonly-explored Co3O4 nanosheet and acid washing of the Co3O4 nanosheet (marked as Co3O4-T) were also synthesized for comparison. Detailed catalysts characterizations, benzene oxidation evaluations, and mechanistic elucidations to support the resultant Co3O4-0.1H displaying enhanced physiochemical properties and catalytic activity than that of La0.029CoOx and Co3O4 counterparts are comprehensively delineated in the following contexts. To examine the crystal structure of the resultant catalysts, XRD patterns were collected. As shown in Fig. 2a, the three samples exhibit identical diffraction patterns. Specifically, peaks positioning at 18.9°, 31.2°, 36.8°, 44.8°, 59.3°, and 65.2° correspond to the (111), (220), (311), (400), (511), and (440) lattice planes of the spinel Co3O4 phase (PDF#43–1003), respectively [27]. Notably, the Co3O4-H samples displayed broader and weaker diffraction peaks compared to the solid La0.029CoOx precursor (Fig. S1), due to the dissolution of surface La species. However, dilute nitric acid had minimal influence on the crystal structure of the original Co3O4, where the non-acid-treated Co3O4 and the acid-treated Co3O4-T exhibited nearly identical diffraction characters (Fig. S2). To assess whether acid treatment affected the textural characteristics of the samples, nitrogen adsorption/desorption tests were conducted. As depicted in Fig. 2b, Co3O4, La0.029CoOx, and Co3O4-0.1H present type-IV isotherms with H3-type hysteresis loops, indicating the presence of mesoporous structures in all three samples [28,29]. Based on the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method, the specific surface areas of Co3O4, La0.029CoOx, and Co3O4-0.1H were determined to be 78.1, 149, and 142 cm2/g, respectively. Fig. 2c reveals that the average pore sizes for Co3O4 and La0.029CoOx were 6.2 nm and 3.6 nm. However, the Co3O4-0.1H sample showed a larger average pore size of 4.7 nm compared to the La0.029CoOx precursor (3.6 nm), which can be attributed to the removal of surface La species, in line with the XRD analysis. The morphological structure of all the as-synthesized three catalysts was visualized using SEM. As observed in Figs. 3a-f, the three samples display two-dimensional nanosheet morphology, among them, Co3O4 exhibits a larger and thicker nanosheet structure than that of La0.029CoOx and Co3O4-0.1H. Noteworthily, the nanosheet morphology of Co3O4-0.1H (Fig. 3e) is perfectly maintained when compared to La0.029CoOx (Fig. 3c), suggesting that acid treatment only removes the inert surface La species, with indiscernible damages to the Co3O4 nanosheet structure. In addition to the well-maintained morphology, a clear difference is that the pore size of Co3O4-0.1H (Fig. 3f) is larger (marked by the red circle) than that of La0.029CoOx sample (Fig. 3d), evidencing that acid treatment enables to increase pore size, consistent with the aforementioned BET analyses. To gain more insight into the structural characteristics of the synthesized catalysts, TEM was adopted. As showcased in Fig. 4, all three samples display a distinct sheet-like morphology, with each sheet composed of interconnected, worm-like nanosheets. Additionally, TEM images revealed that the reference Co3O4 counterpart (Fig. 4a and b) presorted a larger sheet crystal structure compared to the La0.029CoOx precursor (Fig. 4d) and acid-treated Co3O4-0.1H (Fig. 4g). The HRTEM images (Fig. 4c and h) shown lattice spacings of 0.24 nm and 0.47 nm for the Co3O4 and Co3O4-0.1H, corresponding to the (311) and (111) basal planes of Co3O4 [30–32]. For La0.029CoOx, the lattice spacing of 0.24 nm corresponded to the Co3O4 (311) plane (Fig. 4e). Furthermore, as seen in Fig. 4f, the TEM energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (TEM-EDX) mapping confirms a uniform distribution of La, Co, and O elements across the entire La0.029CoOx nanosheet. In contrast, for the Co3O4-0.1H sample, both the TEM-EDX mapping (Fig. 4i) and the EDX spectrum (insert of Fig. 4j) confirmed the absence of La ions, demonstrating that the acid-etching process is an effective strategy for the removal of surface La species. 3.2 Benzene oxidation measurements Benzene was selected as the model pollutant to evaluate the catalytic activities of the as-synthesized catalysts. The effect of varying dilute nitric acid concentrations on catalytic performance was first investigated. As can be seen from Fig. 5a, all the acid-etched catalysts of Co3O4-0.05H, Co3O4-0.1H and Co3O4-0.25H exhibit a significantly higher benzene conversion rate compared to the La0.029CoOx precursor, underscoring the effectiveness of the acid-etching strategy. Among the acid-treated catalysts, Co3O4-0.1H showed the optimal catalytic performance (Fig. 5a). Besides, a comparison of catalytic activity between Co3O4-0.1H, Co3O4, and Co3O4-T was also conducted. As observed in Fig. 5b, the benzene removal performance of non-acid-etched Co3O4 and acid-etched Co3O4-T is similar. This is attributed to the structural stability and robust acid resistance of spinel Co3O4, meaning that the diluted nitric acid treatment will not significantly alter its surface structure. In contrast, Co3O4-0.1H exhibited superior benzene oxidation performance than Co3O4 and Co3O4-T, likely due to its thinner sheet-like structure, higher BET surface area, and greater exposure of active sites [33]. In addition, as can be seen from Fig. S3 that the CO2 yield and the benzene conversion rate are basically identical, indicating that benzene is basically transformed to final CO2. Given the presence of water vapor in practical environments, experiments were conducted to assess the impact of water vapor on the catalytic performance of Co3O4-0.1H. As showcased in Fig. 5 c, the introduction of water vapor indeed reduces catalytic efficiency, with higher concentrations of water vapor leading to more pronounced inhibitory effects. This loss in activity could be attributed to water vapor competes for adsorption or water vapor-associate the formation of incompletely oxidized intermediates on the catalyst surface [34,35]. Next, the effect of different WHSV on catalytic performance was examined. Fig. 5d shows that Co3O4-0.1H exhibits excellent catalytic performance at a relatively low WHSV of 20,000 mL·g−1·h−1, achieving 100 % conversion of benzene at only 220 ℃. This result is comparable to that of some supported catalysts reported in the literature (Table S1). Even at an extremely high WHSV of 120,000 mL·g−1·h−1, the 100 % conversion of benzene was achieved at a relatively low temperature of 250 ℃, again supporting the distinguished activity of Co3O4-0.1H catalyst. Catalytic cycling and long-time-on-stream stability are also critical for evaluating the performance of the prepared samples. Therefore, 5 consecutive cycles and 45 h on-stream test were conducted using the optimal Co3O4-0.1H catalyst. Although catalytic conversion rates slightly decreased with an increasing number of cycles, Co3O4-0.1H maintained 100 % benzene conversion at 230 ℃ under a high WHSV of 60,000 mL·g−1·h−1 (Fig. 5e). Additionally, the 45 h on-stream test at 220 ℃ also showed only a slight decrease in activity, with benzene conversion rates remaining around 90 % over the entire reaction period, demonstrating the well catalytic stability of Co3O4-0.1H catalyst (Fig. 5f). 3.3 Surface property and catalytic mechanism investigation On the fact that Co3O4, La0.029CoOx and Co3O4-0.1H catalysts exhibited different catalytic performance towards benzene oxidation, additional characterizations were carried out to distinguish the different surface characteristics of the catalysts. On this basis, a structure-activity relationship between catalytic performance and surface property can be constructed. Initially, the reducibility of the prepared samples was evaluated using the H2-TPR technique. Fig. 6a shows two distinct peaks for both the Co3O4 and Co3O4-0.1H samples. The first peak corresponds to the reduction of Co3+ to Co2+, while the second peak is due to the reduction of Co2+ to Co0 [36]. Besides, from Fig. 6a, the La0.029CoOx exhibits four reduction peaks, which correspond to the reduction of surface-adsorbed oxygen species, the reduction of Co3+ to Co2+, the reduction of Co2+ to Co0, and the reduction of La-O-Co units, respectively. Notably, compared to original Co3O4 and La0.029CoOx, Co3O4-0.1H present better low-temperature reducibility. Specifically, for Co3O4-0.1H catalyst, the temperature for reduction of Co3+ to Co2+ was 270 ℃, and the temperature for reduction of Co2+ to Co0 was 372 ℃, which was the lowest, attributing to its smaller crystal sizes and thinner sheets. Generally, the catalyst with better low- temperature reducibility indicates that the active sites are more easily involve to the reaction [37], thereby explaining that Co3O4-0.1H catalyst with remarkable low-temperature reducibility displayed optimal catalytic performance for benzene oxidation. To clarify the oxygen adsorption properties of the different catalysts, the O2-TPD test was conducted. Specifically, two distinct desorption peaks are observed for all three catalysts (Fig. 6b). The peak in the 50–200 ℃ range is attributed to the desorption of physically adsorbed oxygen, and the second peak (200–500 ℃) corresponds to the desorption of chemisorbed oxygen [38]. In detail, the physically adsorbed oxygen is formed through the oxygen absorbed by the pores on the catalyst surface, and chemisorbed oxygen is originated from the oxygen chemically absorbed by the defective sites on the catalyst surface. Notably, the La0.029CoOx precursor and the optimal Co3O4-0.1H exhibit significantly larger desorption peak areas compared to the pristine Co3O4 catalyst, indicating superior oxygen adsorption properties, in good coherence with the higher BET surface area. When comparing the optimal Co3O4-0.1H catalyst with the La0.029CoOx precursor, the former shows even better oxygen adsorption characteristics, primarily caused by the removal of inactive La ions, leading to exposing more active sites for oxygen adsorption [26,39]. It is accepted that more physically adsorbed and chemisorbed oxygen on the catalyst surface can participate in the oxidation reaction more efficiently following the entire oxygen activation-consumption-replenishment process. The optimal Co3O4-0.1H catalyst possessing both marked fractions of both physically adsorbed and chemisorbed oxygen, supporting well with its distinct benzene oxidation performance as observed by experimental catalysis evaluation. XPS analysis was conducted to verify the surface elements and their corresponding valence states. The full XPS spectra (Fig. S4) revealed that the Co3O4 and Co3O4-0.1H primarily contain Co, O, and C elements, while the La0.029CoOx consisted of La, Co, O, and C. As to the XPS Co 2p spectra ( Fig. 7a), which displayed two primary peaks of Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2, with each peak can each be further split into two deconvoluted peaks. The peaks at 780.0 and 794.9 eV correspond to Co3+, while those at 781.5 and 796.7 eV are attributed to Co2+ [40]. The proportion of Co3+ was quantified by statistical analysis of the integrated peak areas. As shown in Table S1, the Co3+ ratio in La0.029CoOx and Co3O4-0.1H is nearly identical, indicating that the dilute acid etching removes only the inert La ions without affecting the quantity of active Co sites. Similarly, the XPS Co 2p and XPS O 1 s spectra analyses of Co3O4 and Co3O4-T also showed minimal differences in surface Co3+ and Oads between the two catalysts (Fig. S5). However, the Co3+ levels in La0.029CoOx and Co3O4-0.1H are higher than those in Co3O4. It is widely accepted that Co3+, coordinated with eight oxygen atoms, promotes the formation of oxygen vacancies and the rapid migration of active oxygen [41,42]. The increased Co3+ ratio in La0.029CoOx and Co3O4-0.1H aligns well with the catalytic evaluation results, namely both La0.029CoOx and Co3O4-0.1H outperforming the Co3O4, supporting the widely accepted hypothesis. XPS O 1 s spectra were then utilized to distinguish the types and relative quantities of oxygen species (Fig. 7b). The binding energies at approximately 530.0, 531.6, 533.4 eV correspond to lattice oxygen, chemisorbed oxygen, and surface-adsorbed hydroxyl species, respectively [43–45]. The relative contents of these oxygen species were compared by integrating the peak areas, as itemized in Table S2, the adsorbed oxygen (Oads) levels in La0.029CoOx and Co3O4-0.1H are significantly higher than Co3O4, likely due to the thinner two-dimensional structures of the catalysts, which generate more defect sites. However, since both surface La species and acid-etching-produced defect sites can attract surface chemisorbed oxygen and hydroxyl groups, hence, the Oads ratios in La0.029CoOx and Co3O4-0.1H showed no substantial differences. For La0.029CoOx, peaks at 835.3 eV and 852.1 eV in XPS La 3d spectra correspond to La3+, nevertheless, after acid etching, the signals of XPS La 3d spectra became undetectable (Fig. S6), suggesting the successful removal of surface La species upon the facile acid washing treatment [46]. Noteworthily, many studies have reported that the catalytic oxidation of VOCs over transition metal oxides obey the Mars-van Krevelen (MVK) mechanism, for which the micromorphology and redox ability of the catalyst are the main factors affecting the oxidation efficiency of organic compounds to CO2 and H2O [47–52]. Returning to our study, where experimental results indicated that the optimal Co3O4-0.1H nanosheet catalyst exhibited the best catalytic ability towards benzene oxidation, which accredited to: i) on the one hand, the nanosheet geometry and abundant mesoporous channels provided sufficient sites for mass transfer, resulting in promoted adsorption and diffusion of pollutants; ii) and on the other hand, the reduction capability of Co-based catalysts was dominated by the cyclic redox of Co3+ and Co2+, with a higher Co3+/Co2+ ratio leading to a faster rate for electron acquisition and more Co-active sites for benzene oxidation, thus showing a higher reducibility at a relatively lower reaction temperature. In our case, the Co3+/Co2+ ratio in the porous Co3O4-0.1H was higher than that of non-acid-treated Co3O4, therefore, corresponding to a higher reduction ability than that of Co3O4. Beyond excellent reducibility, the Co3O4-0.1H catalyst also owned rich reactive oxygen species, enabling rapid migration capability of lattice oxygen, for which was caused by the release of oxygen species from La ion bondage. In addition, the acidic etching also rendered exposure of more oxygen adsorption sites, further facilitating the adsorption and activation of oxygen molecules, in turn generating more reactive oxygen species to participate in benzene oxidation. Based on the observed experimental results, together with the characterization analyses, the distinct catalytic activity of Co3O4-0.1H was collectively contributed by its ultrathin nanosheet geometry, copious mesoporous structures and abundant defective sites ( Fig. 8). 4 Conclusions In conclusion, a series of Co3O4-H nanosheets catalysts with large surface area were successfully synthesized by dilute nitric acid etching of the ultrathin La0.029CoOx solid precursor. Among the obtained catalysts, Co3O4-0.1H maintained high specific surface area and an increase in average pore size compared to original La0.029CoOx, attributed to the removal of La species. Catalytic oxidation of benzene demonstrated that Co3O4-0.1H was also most effective catalyst, along with remarkable cyclic stability and long-time operation durability, as evidenced by maintaining a catalytic benzene conversion rate of ∼90 % after 45 h of long-term testing and 5 consecutive cycles. Through various characterization techniques, such distinct catalytic performance of Co3O4-0.1H was attributed to its ultrathin nanosheet structure, higher content of active Co3+ sites, and abundant exposure of active sites. This work provides a case of acid washing approach to synthesizing cobalt oxide catalysts with high specific surface area and enhanced catalytic activity, for which can be found broader applications beyond gas-phase catalysis. coredata.dc:description: Co-based catalysts exhibit considerable catalytic activity in oxidative reactions, yet challenges remain in synthesizing Co3O4 materials featuring both large surface area and high activity. Here, ultrathin La0.029CoOx nanosheets were post-treated with various concentrations of dilute nitric acid to obtain the two-dimensionally geometric Co3O4-H nanosheets catalysts. Among them, the resultant Co3O4-0.1H catalyst disclosed significantly enhanced catalytic activity, enabling to achieve 100 % conversion of benzene at 230 °C under an ultrahigh weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of 60,000 mL·g−1·h−1. Additionally, the catalyst also displayed excellent catalytic durability and well catalytic stability over 5 cyclic tests and 45 h of long-period operation. A thorough characterization results revealed that the superior catalytic performance of Co3O4-0.1H was attributed to its distinct nanosheet morphology, high specific surface area and abundant surface defect sites. This work highlights the effectiveness and simplicity of acid washing treatment strategy in improving the catalytic oxidation activity of transition metal oxide catalysts.
